The tea on the British Empire

14 Oct 2022 by Josh

Central plank of empire apologists

Someone, whose name escapes me, describing I think the American imperial efforts framed the central conceit of empires as being “we came to enlighten and liberate - not exploit and control like all the other empires in history”.

So a common plank of empire apologists is the idea is that one is doing things for the good of the colonised people.

The law on tea cultivation in 2 parts of the British empire

Rebutting this British Empire apology succintly & concretely and on an FYI basis, rather than as its polemical aim, is Advances in Tea Agronomy - in chapter 2 - where it notes for Kenya that a change in the law allowed the indigenous population to grow tea (in 1956 - according to the Tea Board of Kenya) and likewise in Malawi in 1966 (the year Malawi became a Republic).

I don’t think there is a clearer or more succint way of putting that the empire is run for the benefit of imperial power rather than as “a good thing for the benefit of the imperial people” than “banned from growing tea in the land of your birth - while those from the imperial power can grow tea there”.

History pop-quiz

“In the 1930s there were bans by some states that prevented some groups of people carrying on certain business activities in the land of their birth - can you name a group and a state? Can you name any others?” is questioning that may prime British people to, rightly, recall Kristallnacht with its paramilitary assault on Jewish businesses - and the step by step exclusion and murder of Jews by the state in Nazi Germany (starting with the Law for the Restoration of the Professional Civil Service/Gesetz zur Wiederherstellung des Berufsbeamtentums).

The “Can you name any others?” prompt - particularly for white British people - may be the point to discuss how the racism of British colonialism is avoided or forgotten or denied by a good chunk of the British.

Even the removal of restrictions was not aimed at liberation but at control: the Swynnerton Plan in Kenya, in the words of the Special Commissioner of the Central Province, had as an aim “to confirm the landlessness of the rebels” by putting confiscated land into a common land pool - as well as, via land consolidation, creating a middle class (p50 in Ogot, Bethwell et al. (eds.) Decolonization and Independence in Kenya, 1940–93). So Kenyan tea farming being opened up before that of Malawi has less to do with any kind of benevolent administration and more to do with a reaction happening in the context of a rebellion to colonial control. And this reaction was aimed at retaining control rather than conferring freedom.
